critique: This executive order pertains to conscientious objectors during World War II, outlining how they can be assigned to work of national importance under civilian direction. It doesn't directly address typical left-right ideological issues. Immigration is not relevant. The order delegates authority to the Director of Selective Service, but within the existing framework of the Selective Training and Service Act, so it doesn't drastically expand executive power. It involves federal oversight, but also utilizes state and private resources, suggesting a cooperative approach. National security is indirectly relevant as it deals with alternative service during wartime, but it also respects individual conscience. Economic regulation isn't a primary focus. Social inclusion is somewhat relevant as it provides an alternative for conscientious objectors, respecting diverse beliefs.
